Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research:Digital SubCarrier Multiplexing (DSCM) Networks: from the Core to the Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Internet traffic is experiencing a rapid growth driven by massive video streaming, cloud computing and the Internet of Things. Green networking is more important than ever to keep energy consumption under control while still guaranteeing good service quality. Packet switching is the standard practice in high speed Internet, enabled by routers and switches that perform electronic packet store-and-forward at every intermediate node. In a typical router, up to 60 percent of its energy is used for packet forwarding. Circuit switching, on the other hand, does not require per-packet store-and-forward and can potentially be more energy efficient. Current practice places optical circuits on a fixed grid of optical frequences. This fixed grid may waste valuable optical spectrum if an optical circuit is carrying less than the maximum capacity. Thus both the research community and industry are investigating grid-less approaches. In particular, Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing (DSCM)is a circuit-oriented approach with high spectral efficiency and robustness against signal quality corruption and which enables flexible spectrum and grid-less transmission in optical networks.

This project leverages DSCM to extend the circuit-oriented practice from the optical network core all the way to the network periphery (including metro, access and campus segments) ultimately offering dedicated broadband DSCM circuits to end-users. DSCM traffic bypasses both Ethernet switches and Internet Protocol routers, and eliminates the energy consumption associated with their packet store-and-forward requirements. The project also explores a Hybrid-DSCM-Ethernet network architecture in which DSCM circuits and Ethernet frames coexist in the access/campus networks. The transmission and network cross-layer nature of this research effort promotes partnerships among different institutions and research areas, and provides graduate and undergraduate students the opportunity to do research solving real-world scientific problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internet traffic is experiencing a rapid growth driven by massive video streaming, cloud computing and the Internet of Things. Keeping both network complicity and energy consumption under control, while still guaranteeing good service quality is more important than ever. In comparison to the standard packet switching network architecture, circuit switching does not require per-packet store-and-forward and can potentially be much simpler and more energy efficient. Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing (DSCM) – a circuit-oriented approach with high spectral efficiency and robustness against signal quality corruption – enables flexible spectrum and grid-less transmission in optical networks. This project leveraged DSCM to extend the circuit-oriented practice from the optical network core all the way to the network periphery (including metro, access and campus segments) ultimately offering dedicated broadband DSCM circuits to end-users. DSCM traffic can bypass both Ethernet switches and Internet Protocol routers, and eliminates the energy consumption associated with their packet store-and-forward requirements. In order to demonstrate the feasibility of circuit-based optical networking, we have successfully developed a flexible test-bed based on a Virtex7 FPGA platform. On this test-bed we have investigated and demonstrated various real-time DSP algorithms for modulation format transparent frequency up-conversion and down-conversion which are essential for circuit cross-connection in the frequency domain. We have also developed hybrid digital-RF system architecture for the generation of optical and RF super-channels, which allowed much reduced speed requirements on digital electronic circuits such as ADC and DAC.

The transmission and networking cross-layer nature of this research effort promoted interdisciplinary partnerships between two research groups at the University of Kansas (KU) and University of Texas at Dallas (UTD), and provided opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to perform collaborative research solving real-world scientific problems. Especially, we have established and strengthened a close collaboration with the McNair scholars program, which helps underrepresented minorities to be competitive for admission to graduate programs. McNair scholars program not only helped us identifying and recruiting undergraduate students, but also helped these students in their career development through advising and well-designed workshops and outreach activities. All the REU students participated in this project went on to become graduate students.
